Award.AbstractNarration:
The collision of celestial objects can be so powerful that they create distortions in spacetime, known as gravitational waves. Albert Einstein predicted their existence more than 100 years ago, but the effects are so tiny that even Einstein thought they could never be detected. After decades of hard work, the Laser Interferometric Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) finally observed these waves for the first time in September 2015 and this triumph was recognized with a Nobel Prize in Physics in 2017. This award will support the attendance of US scientists to the COFI International Workshop on Gravitational Waves, to be held in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The workshop will convene scientists from across the globe to discuss current and future research in gravitational wave detection, giving priority to the attendance of graduate students and young researchers as part of their formation in the field.

The workshop will gather the world experts to discuss the motivation and the experimental challenges of future measurements of gravitational waves. The discussion will include: Overview of recent detections and prospect for upcoming LIGO/Virgo observing runs, the landscape of electromagnetic follow up programs, science implications to cosmology, tests of general relativity and understanding of low mass binary stars and mergers, and the future of LISA. The agenda for the three days workshop includes about twenty-five presentations summarizing the state of the field in that many aspects of research and data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On 26-27 October 2018 we held the Second Gravitational Waves Workshop at Colegio De Fisica Fundamenal E Interdisciplinaria de Las Americas (COFI) in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The conference was organized by Shane Larson (CIERA/Northwestern University), Marcelle Soares-Santos (Brandeis University), and Mayda Velasco (COFI/Northwestern University).

The workshop was a highly successful follow-on to the First Gravitational Waves Workshop held at COFI in December of 2015. Notably, the First Workshop happened before the announcement of the first detection of gravitational waves, where as this second workshop happened after the end of LIGO's successful second Observing Run and examined the state of gravitational waves in an era when there have been 10 binary black hole detections, and one multi-messenger detection of a binary neutron star. The change in the scientific landscape in just three short years has been dramatic and was highlighted by the broad scope of interests represented by the participants and speakers at the conference.

The workshop featured twelve speakers over two days, representing both traditional electromagnetic astronomers and gravitational wave astronomers, as well as theorists and observers. Talks and discussions were not narrowly focused on LIGO and recent results, but also examined the science enabled by gravitational wave observations across the spectrum, including in pulsar timing arrays and space-based observatories like LISA. Our speaker pool was diverse in geographic and institutional representation, and was comprised of 6 women and 6 men. The conference was attended by approximately 25 people.

Topically we examined both outstanding astrophysical questions that remain after the initial round of source detections, but also examined new opportunities these discoveries enable that will connect to other observing programs and theoretical investigations about the behaviour of sources, implications for populations of sources in the galaxy and universe, and what future opportunities for research in these areas will exist.

Conferences at COFI are excellent in terms of their core design and small group feel. There is ample time for discussion and debate among all the participants, integrating everyone into the scientific explorations being discussed.
